newsitem.title: BELGIUM: FOCUS-Italian incentive scheme boosts EU car sales.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Italian incentive scheme boosts EU car sales.

text.p: New car registrations in western Europe jumped 9.3 percent in April, driven largely by soaring sales in Italy due to a buying incentive scheme, the European Automobile Manufacturers Association said on Wednesday.
Registrations rose to 1,272,100 units from 1,164,100 the same month last year. In the first four months of the year, sales rose 0.8 percent to 4,696,000 cars, ACEA said.

However, there were wide variations between different countries, ranging from an increase of 52.4 percent in Italy in April to a 10.5 percent decline in France following the end of a government incentive scheme last year.
"It is driven by incentives either up or down," said European car industry analyst Philip Ayton at investment bank Barclays de Zoete Wedd in London. "It is not a natural market right now."

The overall market is expected to rise by between one and two percent in 1997, Ayton said. "It is pretty static but within an overall static number there are quite dynamic things happening with some markets strongly up and some much weaker."
ACEA spokesman James Rosenstein estimated 1997 growth at about two percent, despite the strong increase in April.

"We said at the beginning of the year we expected about two percent growth for the overall market and we still think that will be about it," he said. "Europe is no longer a high growth market, nor is the United States and Japan."
But, Rosenstein cautioned, "you never can tell what is going to happen with the incentive effect, how long this kind of growth will be sustained in Italy."

Under the Italian plan, funded by the government and industry, car owners receive discounts on new cars when they trade in cars more than 10 years old. There is also a long-term buying incentive in Spain.
"These incentives have in a sense distorted what would be a normal market evolution," Rosenstein said.
But there were also benefits with such schemes as they helped renew the car stock, increased sales on stagnant markets and benefited the environment.
New car registrations firmed a more modest 2.2 percent to 344,000 cars in Germany, Europe's largest market, but rose by an impressive 12.4 percent to 182,700 units in Britain.
Among individual car groups, Italy's Fiat group saw its new car registrations rise by 23 percent to 159,900 units, giving it a market share of 12.6 percent, second only to German giant Volkswagen AG.
The Volkswagen group's sales firmed 10.4 percent and its share of the western European market increased further to 17.9 percent from 17.7 in the same month in 1996.
U.S. giants General Motors and Ford also showed higher sales, up by 3.4 percent and six percent to 155,013 and 141,102 cars respectively.
New registrations of Japanese cars increased by 6.3 percent to 139,594 but the South Korean figure fell by 4.5 percent to 21,414.
It was also a good month for top-of-the-range brands like Jaguar, up by 43.9 percent to 1,658, and Mercedes, up by 20 percent to 50,200.

Sweden's Volvo saw its figure jump 31.1 percent to 22,670, helped by a 46.5 percent increase in the overall Swedish market following the end to uncertainties about government policy on company car taxation.
